STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
March 1, 2023
Courtney Atkins
ISABELLA COUNTY DHHS
1919 PARKLAND ST,
MOUNT PLEASANT, MI, 48858-6017
Re: License #: CP370201201
Dear Ms. Atkins:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
February 28, 2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 S. Elmwood, Ste. 11
Traverse City, MI 49684
(231) 342-3721
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.12404 Placement
(7) An agency shall document, in the child’s record, within 7
calendar days after placement, the information specified in R
400.12417 (1) and all of the following information:
(h) A photograph of the child at the time of placement.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not have a photograph of the child at the time
of placement as required.
2

R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(1) Agency’s medical and dental care policy shall, at a minimum,
include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows, unless a
greater frequency is medically indicated:
(i) For a child under 2 years of age, a physical examination
shall be completed within 30 calendar days after placement.
One of six open foster care files reviewed did not have an initial medical examination
completed within 30 calendar days after placement as required.
R 400.12417 Foster parent information
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child:
(a) Child's name.
(b) Child's date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child's health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors relating to the
care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or replacement of the
child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster parent to
provide a stable, safe, and healthy environment for the foster
child and the foster family, including information about siblings
who do not reside in the foster home.
Four of six open foster care case files reviewed did not contain documentation that all
information required within subsection a-h of this rule was provided to the caregivers
within the timeframes outlined within the rule.
FOM 801-03 Medical passports
For children entering foster care, the initial medical passport must
be provided within two weeks of the child's placement date to the
following:
• Foster care provider.
• Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC) youth/young
adult re-entering foster care.
The actual date the medical passport is provided must be
documented in the electronic case management record.
3

An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary court
ward.
Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
At reunification. Subsequent medical passports are not
required after reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider:
At or prior to each placement.
• All medical and mental health professionals to whom the child
is newly referred to and accepted for treatment and/or
services prior to or at the first scheduled appointment while
the foster care case is open, regardless of placement.
Subsequent medical passports are not required.
• Older youth/young adults:
Upon initial independent living placement (youth age 16
and over).
Upon exiting the foster care system (young adults age
18 and older).
Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC) youth/young
adult:
Within two weeks of re-entry into voluntary foster care.
Upon exiting voluntary foster care.
Five of six open foster care files reviewed did not have medical passports and
required signatures.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
1/25/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 2/3/2022
2/5/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 2/19/2021
FOM 722-06B FTM Documentation
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in MiSACWIS
using the FTM hyperlink within seven business days of the FTM.
4

Five of six foster care files reviewed contained FTM’s without the DHS 1105 or the
D HS 1105 was not uploaded within seven business days.
FOM 722-08C Foster Care-Parent Agency Treatment Plan & Service
Agreement
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate, including
those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care worker, supervisor,
foster parent, caregiver, any youth aged 14 and older and in the
case of placement agency foster care cases, the local DHS office
designee.
Four of six foster care files reviewed (11 of 16 service plans) did not contain all of the
required signatures on the parent agency treatment plan (PATP).
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
1/25/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 2/3/2022
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• All boxes must be checked if an FTM is being conducted for more than
one purpose.
• Include date emergency procedures were practiced in licensing reports.
• Annotate on signature line of PATP if mailed, emailed, or refused to sign.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• In two foster care files reviewed it was noted youth had an Individualized
Education Plan (IEP), however the IEP’s were not uploaded and the
education section of MISCAWIS was not complete. Be sure to update
education section and uploaded IEP’s as outlined in FOM 723.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. The
corrective action plan was submitted in response to licensing renewal inspection
report dated 1/25/2022 and was approved on 2/3/2022. During the review the
5

agency had seven violations. Two citations were noted as repeat violations in the
current inspection. During this period under review the agency has struggled with
staff turnover as well as supervisory changes.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The assessment reported a review of the agency’s data shows success in meeting a
majority of the requirements during this review period. Chief Administrator (CA)
stated some barriers include COVID related barriers as well as securing a medical
provider to see a youth within 30 days of removal. In addition, the assessment noted
increased staff turnover as well as supervisory changes have impacted compliance.
CA indicated review of missed metrics are completed with staff during case
conferences. Utilizing the Quality Assurance analyst has also been helpful in
meeting expectations. CA also indicated ongoing training has been provided to
assist new staff as they learn their positions.
Financial Overview
No financial concerns were identified.
Staff Interviews
Interviews were conducted with two staff via telephone. Staff acknowledged there
has been an adjustment to new supervision however felt the agency has handled it
well. Staff expressed frustration with challenges related to CWLM but anticipated
improvement in the coming months. Staff reported feeling supported by supervisors
and reported no areas of concern.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care and licensing services. All files were stored securely.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
6

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
___________2/28/2023___________________________
Melinda Gubbins Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
March 1, 2023

Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
